heading: judge: copa went too far
subheading: hours before the controversial child online protection act was to become law, it's declared unconstitutional. what now for net censorship? declan mccullagh reports from washington.
author: wired staff
text: washington -- a new law restricting online erotica violates the first amendment, a federal judge ruled monday, six hours before the measure would have taken effect. saying the child online protection act was a well-intentioned attempt to protect children but that it went too far, us district judge lowell a. reed jr. barred the federal government from enforcing it."perhaps we do the minors of this country harm if first amendment protections, which they will with age inherit fully, are chipped away in the name of their protection," reed wrote in a preliminary injunction memorandum.the american civil liberties union, which brought the lawsuit on behalf of news, art, and sexual-health web sites concerned they would be prosecuted, applauded the decision."the court clearly listened to all of the complicated evidence that was put on at the hearing and recognized that the bottom-line issue was the speech that adults would be deterred from accessing," said ann beeson, an aclu staff attorney who argued the case.reed's earlier temporary restraining order against copa would have expired at midnight est monday.the justice department, which defended the law in court as a modest measure aimed only at pornographers, said it has not yet decided whether it would appeal or ask for a full-blown trial."we need to review the decision before making that determination," said spokesman chris watney.copa, which congress passed as part of a spending measure last fall, makes it a crime to publish "any communication for commercial purposes that includes any material that is harmful to minors, without restricting access to such material by minors." the maximum penalty is us$50,000 fines, six months jail, and additional civil fines.the law defines material that is harmful to minors as anything that describes "an actual or simulated sexual act or sexual contact ... or a lewd exhibition of the genitals or post-pubescent female breast."so far, copa's fate precisely mirrors that of its predecessor, the reviled communications decency act. the supreme court nixed that as unconstitutional two years ago.
